title: Borrow checker prohibits iterating over map-returned array
body:
I'm trying to iterate over a range, return an array and iterate over its elements.
I was going to iterate over returned values as ranges, but sadly I didn't even get to that part.

This doesn't work, but to me it looks like it should:

``` Rust
use std::iter::*;

fn some_arr(x: usize) -> [usize; 3] { [x, x * 2, x * 3] }

fn main() {
    let ans = (1..100).map(|x| some_arr(x)).flat_map(|x| x.iter()).count();
    println!("{}" , ans);
}
```

```
<anon>:6:58: 6:59 error: `x` does not live long enough
<anon>:6     let ans = (1..100).map(|x| some_arr(x)).flat_map(|x| x.iter()).count();
                                                                  ^
<anon>:6:15: 6:75 note: reference must be valid for the method call at 6:14...
<anon>:6     let ans = (1..100).map(|x| some_arr(x)).flat_map(|x| x.iter()).count();
                       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
<anon>:6:58: 6:66 note: ...but borrowed value is only valid for the block at 6:57
<anon>:6     let ans = (1..100).map(|x| some_arr(x)).flat_map(|x| x.iter()).count();
                                                                  ^~~~~~~~
error: aborting due to previous error
```

Tried it on alpha.2, today's nightly and playpen.

PS: ebfull on rust IRC channel kindly suggested a hack, which is using `.collect::<Vec<_>>()` on a map and then iterating over it.
